metadata.case_name: Masood Alam v. Union of India & Ors. and Abdul Bari Kairanvi v. Union of India

facts.text: Masood Alam arrested on June 15, 1972 pursuant to detention order dated June 14, 1972 by District Magistrate, Aligarh under S. 3(1)(a)(i) and (ii) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

Grounds of detention served on Masood Alam on June 17, 1972, alleging exciting communal feelings amongst Muslims, disaffection towards Government, advocating use of force against A.M.U. Amendment Bill, involvement in Youth Majlis (paramilitary organization training in lathi, swords, knives), member of Al Jehad, participation in various meetings and training camps.

Grounds allege extra-territorial loyalties: visited Pakistan, returned April 29, 1971, developed contacts and received money for Muslims in Aligarh; criticized Government policy on Bangladesh on July 16, 1971 with Abdul Bari Qairanvi; attended meeting October 20, 1971 preparing for Indo-Pak situation.

No approval of Masood Alam's initial detention by State Government under S. 3(3); release order served June 26, 1972 at 12 noon citing non-receipt of approval, but detained as under-trial under Rules 107/117 Cr.P.C.
Fresh detention order dated June 25, 1972 by Governor of U.P. under S. 3(1) served on Masood Alam June 26, 1972 at 3:30 p.m., for acting prejudicial to security of State and public order.
Abdul Bari Kairanvi arrested June 3, 1972 for organizing procession defying S. 144 Cr.P.C. order in Aligarh amid communal tension leading to riots on June 5, 1972; arrested under S. 188 I.P.C.

Detention order for Abdul Bari Kairanvi dated June 14, 1972 by District Magistrate under S. 3(1)(a)(i) and (ii) as amended by Defence of India Act; grounds served under S. 8 alleging membership in Muslim Majlis and Youth Majlis, training in arms, fund collection, visit to Pakistan November 1971 for funds, extra-territorial loyalties (propagating Pak policy on Bangladesh, preparing for Indo-Pak clash), exciting communal feelings (speeches against A.M.U. Bill, pamphlets).

Abdul Bari's detention reported to State June 18, approved June 25, reported to Centre June 29; case to Advisory Board July 13, Board decision August 18/21, confirmed August 30; representation July 15/24, considered August 2, conveyed August 5.
Short order on December 20, 1972 directing release of Masood Alam unless required in other case.

legal_issues.text: Whether the second detention order dated June 25, 1972 for Masood Alam is invalid due to lack of fresh facts after expiry/revocation of first order under S. 14 of MISA.
Whether grounds of detention suggest imminent likelihood of prejudicial acts justifying detention.
Whether service of detention order on person in jail custody is invalid.
Whether grounds of detention for both petitioners are irrelevant, vague, or stale.
Whether grounds for Abdul Bari Kairanvi's detention are relevant to security of State and public order.

petitioner_arguments.text: First detention order invalid as grounds only suggest threat under Cr.P.C. Ch. VIII, not justifying MISA; shows mala fides for second order.
No imminent likelihood of prejudicial acts; detention abuses power short of imminent threat.
Service of second order while in jail invalid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab

petitioner_arguments.text: Grounds stale (over a year old); second order on same facts without fresh facts post-revocation/expiry.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. 14 MISA; Hadibandhu Das v. District Magistrate

petitioner_arguments.text: For Abdul Bari, Youth Majlis/Muslim Majlis are social service orgs, not militant; grounds irrelevant/vague.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner's activities highly communal, necessitating detention for security and public order.
Grounds relevant and germane; past conduct justifies subjective satisfaction of future prejudice.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India; Ujjagar Singh v. State of Punjab

court_reasoning.text: First order not mala fide; grounds relevant to MISA despite overlap with Cr.P.C.; preventive detention based on subjective satisfaction distinct from judicial proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdiction of suspicion depends on subjective satisfaction.

court_reasoning.text: No need for objective imminent likelihood; if grounds germane, court cannot substitute view.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Constitutional freedoms subject to reasonable restrictions for larger interests.

court_reasoning.text: Service in custody valid if likely soon released and material shows future prejudice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not futile dual custody if prior custody ceasing soon.

court_reasoning.text: Past conduct proximate and rationally connected justifies detention; not stale.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inference of future prejudice from prior events.

court_reasoning.text: Second order invalid for Masood Alam as no fresh facts post-expiry of first (lapsed after 12 days sans approval); S. 14 bars fresh order on same facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prevents camouflage of successive orders evading max period.

court_reasoning.text: Abdul Bari's grounds relevant: extra-territorial loyalties, pro-Pak propaganda during tensions, inciting communal feelings via speeches/pamphlets, defiance of S.144 leading to riots; Youth Majlis training in arms prejudicial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inciting religious passions threatens public order and State security in secular society.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds not vague; precise instances provided.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts accepted as correct; no appellate inquiry.

holdings.text: Detention order dated June 25, 1972 against Masood Alam quashed due to violation of S. 14 MISA lacking fresh facts.
Detention of Abdul Bari Kairanvi valid; grounds relevant, not vague.
Service of detention order in custody not invalid per se.

outcome.summary: Writ Petition No. 469 (Masood Alam): Detention quashed, release directed on December 20, 1972 unless required otherwise. Writ Petition No. 470 (Abdul Bari Kairanvi): Detention upheld as grounds relevant and procedure followed.
outcome.relief_granted: Release of Masood Alam; no relief for Abdul Bari Kairanvi.

key_quotes.text: The jurisdiction of preventive detention sometimes described as jurisdiction of suspicion depends on subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes preventive detention from punitive proceedings.

key_quotes.text: The revocation or expiry of a detention order shall not bar the making of a fresh detention order under section 3 against the same person in any case where fresh facts have arisen after the date of revocation or expiry.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes S. 14(2) MISA, basis for quashing Masood Alam's detention.

key_quotes.text: Hostility amongst the citizens founded on differences in religious faiths is a deadly poison for healthy existence and progress of a secular, egalitarian society like ours.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains relevance of communal incitement to public order.
